poem:
Salvage

Amidst rust and ruin,  
Jude's hands speak—  
engines whisper,  
cookfires murmur,  
a new world hums  
with her quiet determination.  
In the hushed aftermath  
of cracked earth,  
where words falter,  
her labor sings;  
the grit of rebuilding—  
beyond the ache,  
forges life  
from remnants.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Salvage by Jennifer Mills review – urgent post-apocalyptic novel proposes a better way of living What does it mean to build a new world from the wreckage of a broken one? This question lies at the heart of Jennifer Mills’ mesmerising fifth novel, Salvage – but it’s one that her gruff, defensive protagonist Jude would rather avoid. For most of the novel, Jude has her head down and is hard at work, cooking, fixing engines,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
